name: NPR
text:
Stock prices plummeted Wednesday, amid fears that a spike in coronavirus cases in parts of the country could force the economy into another lockdown.
https://t.co/jwMc9OnJdO

name: NPR
text:
More and more cyclists are taking on “Everesting” — climbing the height equal to Mount Everest by riding a single hill, up and down, over and over again. 

Lachlan Morton just set a record: He finished in seven hours, 29 minutes and 57 seconds.
https://t.co/VB9wIEV1B5

name: NPR
text:
"Very few Americans have created all of their wealth on their own; it's passed down through generations and then built upon," journalist @nhannahjones says.

"You cannot close a racial wealth gap without transferring wealth."
https://t.co/yJTaCj3L3A

name: NPR
text:
Anti-racist protests in Washington State were not a catalyst for the spread of COVID-19, according to a state public health official. 

"What we're finding is, in large part, that's due to the use of masks," she said.
https://t.co/nqtrMns9LF

name: NPR
text:
Several governors, largely in the South and West, have opted to postpone the next phase of their states' reopening in light of growing coronavirus cases and hospitalization numbers.
https://t.co/CB2FAhQNC4

name: NPR
text:
New daily coronavirus cases are rising in 27 states, an NPR analysis shows. 

Here's the percent change compared to 2 weeks ago:

Oklahoma: +255%
Idaho: +176%
Florida: +173%
Arizona: +173%
Texas: +169%
https://t.co/EnrxwdSqtO

name: NPR
text: Some camps and day cares are still giving kids social experiences this summer — from a distance. That means no hugs or high-fives, no big group activities, no field trips, no swimming. (@WBEZ) https://t.co/KxbQ3i72Jj

name: NPR
text:
Electronic artist @jamesblake has spent a lot of time on Instagram Live, playing concerts for thousands.

“Club music takes up a different part of the brain,” Blake says. “I, for one, will be definitely undernourished until we're able to do it again.”
https://t.co/caF8KknJOe

name: NPR
text:
Barack Obama told supporters they need to do more to ensure Joe Biden wins the 2020 presidential race. 

"Whatever you've done so far is not enough. And I hold myself and Michelle and my kids to the same standard," he said Tuesday.
https://t.co/OQTZrWM4go

name: NPR
text:
Joe Biden will formally accept the nomination at the Democratic National Convention in Milwaukee in August, but state delegations have been told to conduct business remotely.
https://t.co/vNEcM9goGf

name: NPR
text:
Naida Lavon was furloughed from her job because of the pandemic — then lost her housing. Now, she lives out of her minivan as she navigates the changing world around her.
https://t.co/o8Dnc2Labo

name: NPR
text:
Montana now has the lowest coronavirus infection rate in the country.

And the pandemic ⁠— and Gov. Steve Bullock's handling of it ⁠— is fast becoming a central issue in his campaign to unseat Republican Sen. Steve Daines.
 https://t.co/rRneiTDRjZ

name: NPR
text:
Today the House and Senate are back in session, at the same time, for the first time since the pandemic began. But access to coronavirus testing remains limited.
https://t.co/9Haak9fnGF

name: NPR
text:
The Los Angeles Times has been hit with a proposed class-action lawsuit — contending that under-representation of people of color at the paper is a result of longstanding discriminatory pay practices against Black, Hispanic and female journalists.
https://t.co/fNGdAG6A4I

name: NPR
text:
Kent County, Michigan — where former President Gerald Ford grew up — has long been Republican turf. But it's also a suburban community that Democrats think they can win in November.
https://t.co/0hWl8ZsouG

name: NPR
text:
Three former staffers of a Michigan youth home have been charged in the death of Cornelius Fredericks —  a Black 16-year-old who died after employees sat on his chest, abdomen and legs to restrain him.

A lawyer said he repeatedly cried: "I can't breathe."
https://t.co/60VzcQ02WA

name: NPR
text:
"Gone With The Wind" has returned to HBO Max, after it was removed this month because of its benign portrayal of slavery.

The film now includes an intro by film scholar Jacqueline Stewart addressing its problematic depictions of the Antebellum South.
https://t.co/OKQGtOoOEF

name: NPR
text:
The Supreme Court has ruled that people who enter the U.S. seeking asylum from persecution elsewhere have no right to a federal court hearing.

The decision allows the Trump administration to fast-track the deportation of thousands of immigrants.
https://t.co/e181MG8rbU

name: NPR
text: RT @nprmusic: 2020 marks the 50th anniversary of the first Pride march in recognition of the Stonewall uprising of 1969. But Pride feels a little different this year. To mark the occasion, we asked music writers to reflect on the changing relationship between Pride, protest and music.2020 marks the 50th anniversary of the first Pride march in recognition of the Stonewall uprising of 1969. But Prid… https://t.co/iRkdSDkXTP

name: NPR
text:
Disney is putting off plans to reopen its southern California parks until state officials issue guidance on how theme parks can allow visitors back.

The company had planned to open both Disneyland and Disney's California Adventure parks on July 17.
https://t.co/wb5yMnTxrE

name: NPR
text:
Misdiagnosis of Black patients is still prevalent today — often by non-Black doctors who misread emotional cues like anger, a psychiatrist says. 

For example, a diagnosis of "'conduct disorder' instead of the result of chronic trauma from racism."
 
https://t.co/AW0OUC8TPB

name: NPR
text:
Texas Gov. Greg Abbott has announced the state will "pause" any further reopening of its economy for now. It comes a day after Texas reported 5,551 new coronavirus cases — its highest daily figure yet.
https://t.co/PjF3WN0KPy

name: NPR
text:
The IRS sent nearly $1.4 billion in coronavirus relief payments to dead Americans.

The improper payments happened due to confusion over whether dead people should receive payments, according to a report by an independent government agency.
https://t.co/zXgCrhW0xY

name: NPR
text:
The country trio Dixie Chicks has changed its name to The Chicks.

The move is accompanied by a new song and video, "March March" — which references protest movements focused on racial justice, police brutality, LGBTQ rights and climate change.
https://t.co/63C644Txlm

name: NPR
text:
The process of coming out can be scary. One piece of advice? You know when it's right for you. If it feels unsafe or you aren't ready, you don't owe anyone your truth.

Here's some advice for navigating coming out—or supporting someone who is (@nprlifekit)
https://t.co/Pe1EFPEBFu

name: NPR
text:
RT @Roughly: In the Netherlands, it’s Sinterklaas, not Santa. Same beard, less paunch. And Instead of elves, he’s got Black Pete (played by white folks in blackface) who many Dutch insist has nothing to do with Black people and is definitely not racist.
New episode 👉🏿 https://t.co/ec4eB13lvY https://t.co/Qd3eXkHGeg

name: NPR
text:
NASCAR released a photo of the noose found in driver Bubba Wallace's garage at the Talladega Superspeedway, saying it was put there in October 2019.  

The organization was unable to determine who "tied the rope in this manner and why it was done."
https://t.co/bzwfxodDk9

name: NPR
text:
The U.S. has had about 10 times more coronavirus cases than were captured by testing, according to new CDC estimates. That would bring the number of Americans who've been infected to at least 20 million.

It also means 90% have yet to be exposed. https://t.co/bTRUm6EA5C
